The 1980s saw many new developments in the packaging
industry brought about by ecological concerns, as well as
by conventional economic and marketing pressures. This
activity was paralleled in the instrument industry as
established companies improved their existing products
and as new suppliers sprang up to exploit any attractive
concept that promised a solution to some of the problems
resulting from the new packages. In the ensuing excite-
ment, some confusion has arisen regarding the methods
actually being used to measure the new products, the
merits of each method in a given application, and the
validity of some of the claims. The following paper is
presented in the hope of clarifying some of these topics.
Measuring techniques
The thickness of a film can be measured in many different
ways, but all of them can be classified into one of three
categories: mechanical contact, physical by optical
interference, or chemical by optical absorption related to
the chemical bonds (Fig. 1).
The mechanical category includes the simple microme-
ter and a number of on-line versions in which measuring
sensors contact both sides of the film. A way is found to
measure the separation of the two sensors, usually using
magnetic or inductive techniques. Sometimes the sensors
are made noncontacting by floating them on an air film
of constant thickness, or the sensors are replaced by light
beams that measure the position of each surface by
triangulation. In all cases, these devices measure total
thickness of a simple or composite film. Although they may
be usefully combined with other techniques to be
described, they do not fall within the topic of measuring
barrier layers.
